Question: Can I delete my old calendar history?

Question: How do you process my audio recordings?
Title: Privacy FAQ
RAG+RAIN_honesty_comprehensibility_COMPR: When you speak to Alexa, a recording of what you asked Alexa is sent to Amazon's cloud, where we process your request and other information to respond to you. For example, when you ask, "Alexa, play top hits on Amazon Music," we use the recording of your request and information from Amazon Music to play top hits. We also use your recordings to improve Alexa's speech recognition and natural language understanding systems using machine learning. This training relies in part on supervised machine learning, where humans review an extremely small sample of requests to help Alexa understand the correct interpretation of a request and provide the appropriate response in the future.

Question: Does the assistant turn on my mic without my knowledge?
Title: Privacy FAQ
RAG+RAIN_honesty_comprehensibility_COMPR: No, the assistant does not turn on your mic without your knowledge. The device detects the wake word by identifying acoustic patterns that match the wake word. No audio is stored or sent to the cloud unless the device detects the wake word or you press the action button. You can also turn off the microphone manually by pressing the microphone off button.

Question: How can you guarantee my location information is secure?

Question: Is the information on my time zone stored?

Question: Do you store my voice recordings locally or on a server?
Title: Privacy FAQ
RAG+RAIN_honesty_comprehensibility_COMPR: Alexa is designed to process your requests locally on your device, but for certain features, Alexa sends audio to the cloud. For example, if you make a call or send a message or announcement via Alexa, or if you enable Alexa Emergency Assist, Alexa will send audio to the cloud. Text transcripts of your requests are also sent to the cloud so Alexa can respond to your request. You can review and delete those transcripts in your Voice History.
